item.title: Russian Internet Outages Soar as Kremlin Boosts War Controls
item.description: Russia is regularly switching off mobile internet connections in large swaths of the country for security reasons, in a sign of the Kremlin’s growing ability to control popular access to technology.
item.dc:creator: Laura Avetisyan

media:content.media:description: A woman uses her mobile phone at an observation point in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia.

item.title: Energy-Efficient Chipmaker Ambiq Micro Files for US IPO
item.description: Ambiq Micro Inc., a maker of ultra-low power semiconductors, has filed for an initial public offering as tech companies try to address the power consumption challenges posed by artificial intelligence computing.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: Technicians perform production control tasks in the cleanroom during the semiconductor manufacturing process.

item.title: CoreWeave Gets First New, High-End Nvidia AI Chips From Dell
item.description: CoreWeave Inc. said it has received the market’s first artificial intelligence server system based on the newest, high-end Nvidia Corp. chip, a sign of its rising stature in the competitive AI cloud-computing space.
item.dc:creator: Dina Bass

item.title: Latin American VC Activity Slows to Near Pre-Pandemic Lows
item.description: Venture capital dealmaking in Latin America has hit the slowest pace in almost seven years, in part due to global economic uncertainty and a pullback from US investors in the region.
item.dc:creator: Maria Clara Cobo

item.title: Summit Is in Talks for $15 Billion Partnership With AstraZeneca
item.description: AstraZeneca Plc is discussing a partnership deal with Summit Therapeutics Inc. in which it could pay as much as $15 billion over time to license a lung-cancer drug, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Michelle F Davis, Dinesh Nair

media:content.media:description: The AstraZeneca facility in Gaithersburg, Maryland.

item.title: Chip Design Software Makers Win US Reprieve in China Trade Deal
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration has lifted recent export license requirements for chip design software sales in China, as Washington and Beijing implement a trade deal for both countries to ease some restrictions on critical technologies.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins

media:content.media:description: Siemens AG. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Thoma Bravo Agrees $2 Billion Deal to Take Olo Private
item.description: Thoma Bravo has struck a $2 billion deal to acquire restaurant software maker Olo Inc. in a sign that private equity firms are still able to find bargains in hot equity markets.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould

media:content.media:description: The company serves more than 750 restaurant brands, including Denny’s Corp.

item.title: Influencers Urged to Steer Clear of Hot Topics During US Immigration Crackdown
item.description: Lawyers are advising content creators that weighing in on political topics can come with serious risks
item.dc:creator: Cecilia D'Anastasio, Aisha Counts, Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: Khaby Lame

item.title: Chip-Design Firm SkyeChip Says Close to Malaysian IPO
item.description: Malaysian semiconductor designer SkyeChip Bhd. is “close” to an initial public offering after posting consecutive years of revenue and profit growth, said Chief Executive Officer Fong Swee Kiang.
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Silicon wafer.

item.title: Meta’s Threads Offers Changes In Effort to Regain Relevancy
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Kurt Wagner reports on some changes to Meta’s Threads and whether it’s enough for the social network to gain cultural relevance.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: The Threads app on a smartphone.

item.title: The Man Tasked With Ending Citigroup’s Fat-Finger Blunders
item.description: Just before Citigroup Inc.’s tech chief faced his first global town hall meeting, he got some pointed advice from his teenager: Make sure the technology works.
item.dc:creator: Todd Gillespie

media:content.media:description: Tim Ryan

item.title: Switzerland, Germany Sign Pact for Joint Sky Shield Initiative
item.description: Switzerland and Germany have agreed to jointly purchase multiple ground-based air defense systems as part of the European Sky Shield Initiative, in a push by the two countries to ramp up collaboration in defense procurement.
item.dc:creator: Levin Stamm

media:content.media:description: A German IRIS-T air defense system.

item.title: ASML, Airbus, Mistral Ask EU to Delay Start of AI Act Rules
item.description: European companies including ASML Holding NV, Airbus SE and Mistral AI have called on the European Union to suspend the implementation of its landmark artificial intelligence regulation for two years because they say it puts the continent’s AI ambitions at risk.
item.dc:creator: Gian Volpicelli

media:content.media:description: An ASML extreme ultraviolet machine cleanroom.

item.title: Intralot in Early Talks With Buyers for Share Capital Hike
item.description: Intralot is in preliminary discussions with investors for its upcoming €400 million ($470.6 million) share sale, a move that comes after it agreed to buy Bally’s Interactive International business, the company’s incoming chief executive officer said.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas

media:content.media:description: The Ballys Resort in Atlantic City, New Jersey.

item.title: ‘Sonic’ Creator Sega Seeks Growth in China and Southeast Asia
item.description: Sega Corp. is teaming up with international partners to expand in Asia and lower its reliance on the Japanese market.
item.dc:creator: Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Sega Corp. video-game characters.

item.title: Former OpenAI Board Member Questions Zuckerberg AI Hiring Spree
item.description: Meta Platforms Inc.’s lavish multimillion-dollar budget for recruiting top AI talent may not guarantee success, said Helen Toner, former OpenAI board member and director of strategy at Georgetown’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology.
item.dc:creator: Saritha Rai, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Visitors near the Meta Platforms headquarters in Menlo Park, California, US.

item.title: Foxconn Pulls Chinese Staff From India in Hurdle for Apple
item.description: Foxconn Technology Group has asked hundreds of Chinese engineers and technicians to return home from its iPhone factories in India, dealing a blow to Apple Inc.’s manufacturing push in the South Asian country.
item.dc:creator: Sankalp Phartiyal, Debby Wu, Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: Signage at the Foxconn Technology Group's campus in Shenzhen, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s DeepSeek Ramps Up Hiring With Job Posts on LinkedIn
item.description: DeepSeek is ramping up its recruitment on LinkedIn, suggesting the Chinese AI startup may be looking to lure talent from outside its homeland.
item.dc:creator: Newley Purnell

media:content.media:description: The logo of the DeepSeek artificial intelligence app, arranged in Riga, Latvia.

item.title: Tata Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy Out Investors in Resurgent
item.description: Tata Group is in talks to buy out other shareholders in Resurgent Power Ventures Pte, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Baiju Kalesh, Sanjai P R

media:content.media:description: The production line at the Tata Power Co. 4.3 GW Solar Cell and Module Manufacturing Plant in Tirunelveli, India. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg

item.title: India’s E-Commerce Stocks Outrun Chinese Peers on Profit Hopes
item.description: India’s top e-commerce stocks have outpaced local indexes and regional peers over the past month, as a rapid rebound fuels bets on their ability to edge out rivals and boost profitability.
item.dc:creator: Diksha Rajput

media:content.media:description: A Swiggy delivery worker in Mumbai. Photographer: Abeer Khan/Bloomberg

item.title: AirPod Maker Luxshare Is Said to Pick Banks for HK Listing
item.description: Luxshare Precision Industry Co. is working with China International Capital Corp., Citic Securities Co. and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. on its planned Hong Kong listing, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti, Dong Cao

media:content.media:description: Luxshare helps make Apple AirPods

item.title: Tesla’s Sales Fall But Investor Support Stays Strong | Bloomberg Tech 7/2/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss the drop in Tesla’s second-quarter sales. Plus, Foxconn pulls Chinese workers from India in a blow to Apple. And, Microsoft plans a second large round of layoffs as it looks to spend more on artificial intelligence. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oracle, OpenAI Expand Stargate Deal for More US Data Centers
item.description: OpenAI has agreed to rent a massive amount of computing power from Oracle Corp. data centers as part of its Stargate initiative, underscoring the intense requirements for cutting-edge artificial intelligence products.
item.dc:creator: Brody Ford, Rachel Metz

media:content.media:description: The Oracle offices in Redwood City, California.

item.title: MARA's Thiel Sees Huge Institutional Interest in Bitcoin
item.description: MARA CEO Fred Thiel discusses the demand for crypto, the state of the Bitcoin-mining industry and MARA's business strategy with Carol Massar and Matt Miller on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: SoftBank Sells $4.2 Billion in Dollar, Euro Bonds Amid AI Push
item.description: SoftBank Group Corp. priced $4.2 billion of bonds in dollars and euros Wednesday, as the technology investment firm turns to global debt markets to accelerate its push into artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Takahiko Hyuga, Ronan Martin

media:content.media:description: A SoftBank Corp. store in Yamato, Japan.

item.title: Microsoft Makes Deep Job Cuts Across Xbox Division, Cancels Games
item.description: Hundreds of people were laid off as the company canceled upcoming games such as Perfect Dark and Everwild
item.dc:creator: Jason Schreier

media:content.media:description: An Xbox games controller

item.title: Six Observations From Summer Game Fest
item.description: E3 is no more, but June is still a good time for new video games
item.dc:creator: Jason Schreier

media:content.media:description: Onimusha: Way of the Sword was one of the many games demonstrated at this year’s Summer Game Fest

item.title: Uber-Backed Moove Raising $1.2 Billion in Debt for Expansion
item.description: African ride-hailing startup Moove is close to raising $1.2 billion in a debt round that will help it finance a rollout of an autonomous-driving fleet with Alphabet Inc.’s Waymo and expand in the US, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Loni Prinsloo

media:content.media:description: Waymo cars at a Waymo facility.

item.title: TikTok Cuts More Workers From US E-Commerce Division
item.description: TikTok is cutting more workers from its US e-commerce division, TikTok Shop, the third round of layoffs for that team since April.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: TikTok Shop and logo displayed on screens in Guildford, south of London on April 17, 2025.

item.title: US Probes Whether Negotiator Took Slice of Hacker Payments
item.description: Law enforcement officials are investigating a former employee of a company that negotiates with hackers and facilitates cryptocurrency payments during ransomware attacks, according to a statement from the firm, DigitalMint.
item.dc:creator: Jake Bleiberg

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk past the US Department of Justice headquarters in Washington, DC.
